newsitem.title: USA: Dole says not sure if wife plans White House run.
newsitem.headline: Dole says not sure if wife plans White House run.

text.p: Bob Dole, who lost the presidential race last year to Bill Clinton, left the door open in remarks broadcast Monday to a possible White House bid by his wife.

Dole, in an interview taped last week for the NBC television programme "Today," denied a suggestion that his recent $300,000 loan to House Speaker Newt Gingrich was designed to promote the political prospects of his wife, Elizabeth Dole.
"No, I don't think that's a matter of great interst to her right now," he said of a White House race for his wife, a two-time cabinet member who now heads the American Red Cross.
Pressed on whether she would run, Dole said: "I don't know. I think we'll ... They're already taking polls, if you can believe it, on the race in 2000."
Asked how Mrs Dole fared in such polls, Dole, the former Senate Republican leader, said: "She does pretty well."
He said he had not discussed his loan to Gingrich with her beforehand "and she was a little surprised."
"I said, 'Well, you know, I think it's the right thing to do'," he went on. Asked whether his wife had objected, he replied: "Nope, it was my money."
Gingrich, a Georgia Republican, needed the funds to pay a $300,000 penalty for violating House of Representatives' ethics rules.

Dole, asked about the alleged "sweetheart" deal he gave Gingrich on the collateral-free, 10-percent interest loan that is payable in eight years, joked that Gingrich was now walking his dog, Leader, in exchange.
Asked whether Gingrich was doing a good job at this, Dole quipped: "Not bad. Always brings him back."
